headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Invest
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our fourth quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks, fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our fourth quarter 2010 results. 
In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks, followed by Q&A. A presentation is available at our website, www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release, provides the basis for most of our remarks.
Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. And actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This conference call is being webcast, and replays will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon.
Once again, we ask that callers limit themselves to one question, so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask your questions. If you have further unanswered questions, please get back into the queue and ask another question, time permitting.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marshall, who will provide you with an overview of our fourth quarter results and our outlook for 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks Paul. You've all had the opportunity to read today's earnings release and the related presentation. Today, I'll begin with our fourth quarter results and then turn to our improved earnings outlook for 2011 and discuss its drivers. We closed out a
componenttext:
Thanks Paul. You've all had the opportunity to read today's earnings release and the related presentation. Today, I'll begin with our fourth quarter results and then turn to our improved earnings outlook for 2011 and discuss its drivers. 
We closed out a solid 2010 with a very strong fourth quarter results. Our net income per diluted share grew 41% on sales growth of 10%. All of our major market channels, including the commercial aftermarket, reported year-over-year sales growth that. Our large commercial airplane original equipment market channel grew by 10%. Our regional business and general aviation original equipment market sales increased by about 52%, which included organic growth of about 20%. Commercial aftermarket sales were 12% higher than the fourth quarter last year. Our defense and space sales continued their positive growth trends in the fourth quarter of 2010, increasing by 9% compared to the fourth quarter of 2009. Our acquisition of Atlantic Inertial Systems contributed 7% of this growth, while organic sales growth was about 2%. 
In the fourth quarter 2010, we achieved segment operating income margins of 15.8% compared to 14.2% in the fourth quarter of 2009, which helped us increase our net income per diluted share from $0.82 in the fourth quarter 2009 to $1.16 in the fourth quarter 2010. The overall improvement was due to strong sales growth, excellent operational performance, relentless pursuit of continuous improvement, a lower tax rate and increased favorable changes and estimates for certain long-term contracts, partially offset by costs associated with the early retirement of debt. 
Specifically, as we discussed with you last October, the fourth quarter 2010 results included debt redemption costs of approximately $0.17 per diluted share. We reported an effective tax rate of 8.5% for the fourth quarter 2010 compared to an effective tax rate of 29.5% during the fourth quarter 2009.
Fourth quarter 2010 tax rate included previously announced tax benefit of approximately $0.18 per diluted share related to a settlement with the California Franchise Tax Board concerning issues related to Goodrich and Rohr for all tax years through 2001 and approximately $0.11 per diluted share for the full year 2010 benefit of the R&D tax credit, which was renewed by the U.S. Congress in late 2010.
Our fourth quarter 2010 results included higher pretax income of $8 million, $5 million after-tax or $0.04 per diluted share related to changes in estimates for certain long-term contracts, primarily in our Aerostructures and Aircraft Wheels and Brakes businesses compared to the fourth quarter of 2009. 
changes and estimates for the fourth quarter 2010 were $27 million pretax. The fourth quarter 2010 included a total pretax restructuring charges of $7 million, $4 million after-tax or $0.03 per diluted share. These actions were not included in our prior outlook for the 2010 earnings.
Net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures or free cash flow for the fourth quarter 2010 was a use of cash of $114 million. As we discussed during our last conference call, we made $300 million of incremental contribution to our pension plans in October. Excluding this incremental contribution, our free cash flow conversion of net income would have easily exceeded 100%.
Since last October, we have announced significant progress on existing programs and several new business wins. We have begun environmental testing of the first operational response of satellite. We signed a 10-year service agreement with Air Arabia for the support of thruster in the airlines' fleet more than 50 A320 aircraft. 
We were selected by Airbus to provide the main landing gear for the aircraft. This contract is expected to generate more than $2 billion in original equipment and aftermath that revenue for us over the life of the program. And we received a production contract from Lockheed Martin to supply a 160 pylons to the U.S. Air Force C5 enhancement and reengining program.
For our full year 2010, we reported a 4% increase in sales to $7 billion, and our income from continuing operations increased from $560 million in 2009 to $577 million in 2010. On a per share basis, we reported income from continuing operations per diluted share over $4.50 in 2010.
For the full year 2010, our large commercial airplane original equipment sales increased by 4%. Regional business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales grew by 2%, including sales associated with DeCrane acquisition. Organically, sales in this market channel decreased by about 5%. 
Large commercial regional business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales were flat compared to 2009. Defense and space sales grew by about 11%, including sales generated by the AIS acquisition. Organic growth in this market channel was 3%.
For 2010, our free cash flow was approximately 50% of income from continuing operations, including the incremental $300 million pension contribution made in the fourth quarter. Excluding this incremental contribution, free cash flow was approximately 102% of income from continuing operations. 
Now I'll turn to 2011. We believe the strong growth trends we experienced in late 2010 will continue in 2011, and we expect significant sales growth in each of our market channels. Overall, we expect sales to grow about 11%, which would provide us with record sales of $7.7 billion to $7.8 million in 2011. 
Based on the recent improvements in airline capacity trends, improving airline profitability and increasing demand trends for our commercial aftermarket products, we are raising our sales growth expectations for commercial aftermarket sales to a range of 7% to 9%. This strong sales growth should result in an even better growth in net income per diluted share. Largely driven by increased expectations for commercial aftermarket sales and lower pension expense, we now expect 2011 net income per diluted share to be in the range of $5.30 to $5.45, an increase of 18% to 21% compared to 2010.
As I noted, we expect sales growth in 2011 in every market channel, including large commercial airplane original equipment sales growth of about 15%. We are assuming that all announced production rate increases are implemented. And Boeing 787 and 747-8 deliveries are consistent with the latest agile announced by Boeing. Regional business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales are expected to grow by about 30%, including incremental sales associated with the DeCrane acquisition. Organically, we expect sales to increase by about 6%.
Large commercial regional business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales are expected to increase by about 7% to 9%.  And defense and space sales of both original equipment and aftermarket products and services are expected to increase by about 7% to 9%. 
Our 2011 outlook includes operating margins of about 16.5%. This reflects growth in aftermarket and the benefit of continuous improvement and lean initiatives on costs, offset by a very rapid growth in lower-margin commercial original equipment and cost-plus military contracts.
Lower worldwide pretax pension expense of approximately $74 million or $0.37 per diluted share. The estimate for 2011 pension expense is based on the 2010 actual return on U.S. plan assets of 14% and a 2011 U.S. discount rate of 5.67%. 
In addition, we have reduced our long-term rate of return assumption on U.S. plan assets to 8.25% as of January 1, 2011, compared to our prior assumption of 8.75%. 
For 2011, we expect total worldwide pretax pension expense of approximately $88 million compared to $162 million in 2010.
We are expecting a 2011 full year effective tax rate of approximately 30%, somewhat higher than the rate we experienced in 2010. 
We continue to expect net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures to exceed 85% of net income for 2011. Our outlook includes expected capital expenditures of $300 million to $350 million and pretax worldwide pension plan contributions of about $100 million. 
We read a lot of questions about our defense programs and our ability to continue to show significant growth in this market 2010. Our defense programs are characterized by diversity and criticality. We are in almost every platform in the defense industry today, both OE and aftermarket. A significant portion of our sales are to international customers, either directly or through foreign military sales contracts. We expect that trend to continue. 
In many cases, we have content on multiple platforms competing for an award, such as the Air Force U.S. tanker competition, where we'll positioned in both the Boeing 767 and the Airbus A330. We have strong positions in a number of large defense programs, which will grow over the next several like the C5 reengining, the F-35 and the C-130. As we have previously discussed in our presentations, we are well positioned in growth markets like helicopters and ISR. We have substantial ships helicopters like the Black Hawk, the Apache and the CH-47. Another area of strength for Goodrich is our ISR sensors. The U2 with our multi-spectral imaging sensor is being test more than ever, and the Goodrich TV110 or seven great success with numerous international customers and has received new international contract awards.
Finally, we also play a big part in the rpecision weapons program of the U.S. and foreign militaries with our actuation and inertial guidance systems. So overall, we feel we are well positioned to the U.S. and allied troops with vital and cost-effective equipment that will result in continued good growth in our defenses-based sales. 
Overall, our performance during the fourth quarter was excellent from an operational standpoint, and we are looking forward to a strong 2011. We continue to expect long-term sustainable growth in sales and earnings fueled by our significant market share gains on new commercial and military aircraft currently in development and steadily increasing commercial aftermarket sales. 
Our financial position remains excellent, with about $800 million of cash on our balance sheet, significant cash flow expectations for 2011 and no significant debt maturities until 2016. This will allow us the flexibility to continue to seek acquisition opportunities that further enhance our sales and earnings growth, contribute to cash generation and drive shareholder value.
I'm looking forward to talking to all of you during 2011. We have a great team, and we're all very excited about continuing to grow the company and our profits as we enter a period of strong commercial aerospace growth. 
With that, let's open it up to questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we raised of our aftermarket forecast. To the 7% to 9%, Heidi. And as I mentioned in the fourth quarter, we continue to see what we think is a harbinger of better things to come and our Wheel and Brake business, where our landings have be
componenttext: Well, obviously, we raised of our aftermarket forecast. To the 7% to 9%, Heidi. And as I mentioned in the fourth quarter, we continue to see what we think is a harbinger of better things to come and our Wheel and Brake business, where our landings have been steadily increasing. And we were starting January in many of our businesses with a much larger backlog than we had in January of last year. So orders are coming in. And particularly in our Aerostructures business, the orders a were majors have turned up in the fourth quarter. That's a very good sign that airlines are having to do some restocking on parts that they've avoided buying in the past because they've had a lot of spare engines out there. So it's not any one thing, we're just kind of seeing a lot of our aftermarket businesses see a much better level of activity, which gave us the confidence to raise that forecast.

componenttext: Marshall, jumping between various calls this morning, so you may have addressed this a little bit. But could you talk about the moving pieces of the revenue guidance? You just mentioned he took aftermarket up,but a couple of other things went down.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the military side, we changed the guidance in terms of growth rates. But the absolute dollars for 2011 are pretty similar to what we would have expected back in October. So we had a little bit softer sales level in the fourth quarter of 2
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the military side, we changed the guidance in terms of growth rates. But the absolute dollars for 2011 are pretty similar to what we would have expected back in October. So we had a little bit softer sales level in the fourth quarter of 2010. But if you look at the dollars sell value in 2011, it's fairly advantage. So the only other market segment of that we changed a bit was regional business, general aviation, where we took those sales down by around $50 million from our prior guidance. That's mostly on the business jet market. And just to give you a little bit of color there, first of all, it's a relatively small part of our total sales, 4%, 5% when you look at OE and aftermarket. So it's not a huge part of our business. But we're seeing good underlying trends that would suggest momentum in that marketplace is starting to develop. So things that we'd look for are the used aircraft prices began to stabilize, we see better activity levels across the current business jet fleet. in the seeing good growth and good aftermarket relate to the business jets. And what we're seeing in the OE said there is decent expectations for growth in OE sales rates, production rates on the larger aircraft. But the smaller, small and midsize aircrafts have not yet seen of those kinds of increases. So our general view is the small and medium growth rates are pushed out to 2012 from where we were thinking they could occur in the second half of '11, previously. So that's the major change in our sales guidance there. And On commercial OE, we took those down from a range of 15% to 20% growth in October, down 15% to 20% and that's all related to changed expectations on 787.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Just one last question on airline maintenance. Have you noticed any behavior change back toward normal from the airlines. Through the recession, they were very tight on how they did maintenance? Everything was another last minute. Anything that could be put off was put off, cannibalizing parts, all that sort of thin. Have you seen any loosening?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Well, I think the biggest an indicator is the majors on aerostructures, the reversers.They've really were avoiding doing because they have aircraft that were being utilized as heavily. And I think that's an indicator to us between that and the backlog on our Wheel and Brake business and the increased landings indicate to me that their getting towards the end of the rope in terms of having to meet restock.

And the offset then obviously is a much better aftermarket environment, which is good margins, so it offsets lot of that change.

componenttext: Yes, there are few higher cost items in the fourth quarter. We booked about $3 million or so of restructuring costs in the quarter in compensation cost, generally, we are higher as the corp G&A out level than our normal levels and that was probably $6 million, $7 million. And each segment have higher comp cost as well in the $2 million, $3 million range per segment. Between those two, there's $5 million, $6 million of cost in the fourth quarter that aren't they are on a normal basis, so that's or most the point of margin right there. And then as Marshall said, we ended the quarter with a decent backlog and will the Wheel and Brake. So there was timing of shipments that moved from first quarter to first quarter of 2011 that changed that margin picture in the fourth quarter just a little bit. So those three factors are mostly the gap between our normal margins levels of little over 11% to work they were in the fourth quarter of about 10.

And then in one of the slides, you've got some benefit that you expect in 2011. Related to foreign exchange. Talk a little bit about but that's coming from and what the volatility might be there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, restructuring, those are just relatively small facility consolidation restructuring that we had expected to do sometime in 2011 or even 2012. And frankly, with the benefit of the R&D tax credit and some of the other upsides we saw, we decide
componenttext: Sure. I mean, restructuring, those are just relatively small facility consolidation restructuring that we had expected to do sometime in 2011 or even 2012. And frankly, with the benefit of the R&D tax credit and some of the other upsides we saw, we decided to pull those in a little bit faster, is that those activities are there and get the benefits and are as well. So there were just two different facilities that we looked at there. Of the foreign exchange side, what we're looking at bear in 2011 is about $20 million benefit versus 2010 in terms of foreign exchange change exposure and hedge cost in 2011 versus '10. And we're about 93% hedged going into 2011. So there's shouldn't be a lot of volatility around that number. And then when we look forward into 2012, we could see an additional $25 million benefit on top of the benefit we have in 201, if exchange rates stay about where they are today. And we're about 73% hedged in 2012. And then we're about 60% hedged in 2013 and there will be a modest benefit in addition in 2013 over 2012, but it's in the $2 million, $5 million range.

componenttextpreview: Like you said, we upped our guidance by $0.25 to $0.35. So the big factors are pension, as mentioned, which is about a $0.21, $0.22 benefit. I mean I would point out that not all about pension expense reduction actually flow through earnings in 2011 becau
componenttext: Like you said, we upped our guidance by $0.25 to $0.35. So the big factors are pension, as mentioned, which is about a $0.21, $0.22 benefit. I mean I would point out that not all about pension expense reduction actually flow through earnings in 2011 because some of it get caught up in inventory and some of already reflected in our contract as it is. So assuming that, that's about $0.20, aftermarket sales we took our guidance up by two percentage points, and we've said about $0.06 per share price point in growth. So that's about $0.12 of increase there. And then the offset would be a slightly slight reduction in sales in RBG OE, so business jet OEM market that we spoke of a moment ago. And then we do have expectation for a little bit higher core cost in 2011 than we did earlier and that's frankly all due to the stock price that we're enjoying. So whatever else the GAAP a couple cents is operational performance on the margin line.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're seeing a ramp-up of costs that we took out over the last couple of years. I mean that's really been a disciplined approach that were centered around lean and CI. And is that culture spread to run the company, the cost that the because
componenttext: I don't think we're seeing a ramp-up of costs that we took out over the last couple of years. I mean that's really been a disciplined approach that were centered around lean and CI. And is that culture spread to run the company, the cost that the because of productivity focus, those are not coming back. I mean we didn't take the easy actions, like salary reductions and the 401(k) freezes and things like that across the enterprise. So we don't have a headwind of cost that have to come back into the system. So we really not really seeing those kind of pressures. So we'll continue to drive margin enhancement, as long as the mix of sales growth between OE and aftermarket stays reasonably aligned. That tends to be the biggest difficulty that we have. And obviously with the pension cost reduction, that's going to be helpful in terms of margins going forward as well. So that's kind of how we see the margin story. Again, to focus on the margin story the fourth quarter, a lot of that was unusual costs. And in terms of restructuring, higher compensation cost that we incurred during the quarter, just timing of some of the higher margin military and aftermarket sales. So you bridge those couple of three things, the margin performance in the quarter was in line with what we're thinking going into 2011 and with prior quarters.

componenttext: Well, we actually have a matrix or metrics that we show the Board of Directors every quarter that lists every SBU and also categories of cost reduction that we achieved lean CI and restructuring and low cost country sourcing. And so we'll go completely through direct, indirect expenses. We have a fairly large bogey for the year that we've achieved or exceeded each of the last number of years. And is really is back to what Scott was saying, doing this in a very methodical manner of continuous improvement that has a cost out of the system. An example, we did in our seeding business -- I'm not sure. Did I talk about it in the fourth quarter?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the fourth quarter, we took our Colorado Springs aircraft seating business and over the course of one week, completely relaid out the whole plant based on one piece flow continuous improvement, where we think will provide his double-digit gains in thro
componenttext: In the fourth quarter, we took our Colorado Springs aircraft seating business and over the course of one week, completely relaid out the whole plant based on one piece flow continuous improvement, where we think will provide his double-digit gains in throughput and productivity and cost decrease. And nothing was sacred. I mean, we moved monuments. We did everything. We moved all the electrical connections, all the air connections, everything. And as Scott said earlier, this is really becoming a culture across this company. We improved our linearity of cash flow just last year instead of everything towards the end of reporting periods based on continuous improvement events that our segment president started of the early part of the year. And we have about close to 10% of our employee equivalents in low-cost country. We have mentioned that. We measure the throughput and improved quality and put on-time delivery that comes through this in terms of operational that a lot of cost metrics also and that's what allowed us to keep the margins reasonably high even in the financial downturn and why we think we can continue to move margins positively.

componenttext: I think we can in a lot of areas. I mean sometimes, there will be an anomaly like titanium costs a few years back, there was a two-year backlog on forging. That's hard to contain that much. But they still hit our bogey in those years overall. We just didn't hit it in the Landing Gear business because of the made up for it in other areas. So yes, I believe we can.

componenttext: It's all blocking and tackling in our functions and our facilities. So certainly, those areas and some of our businesses haven't made as much progress so it's lower hanging fruit. But even the ones that have really been relentless on continuous improvement are able to glean more and more by revisiting even the same process we've already leaned out a year or two back. So I don't see it ever changing. I think we're early in the game on this . whole thing.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: A lot of it depends on where we need it. Because we don't just move manufacturing out of the U.S. or Europe because there are lower cost areas in the road. A lot of it is where the demand is. We are able to reduce our whole supply chain by sourcing for cu
componenttext: A lot of it depends on where we need it. Because we don't just move manufacturing out of the U.S. or Europe because there are lower cost areas in the road. A lot of it is where the demand is. We are able to reduce our whole supply chain by sourcing for customers closer to them. But it also has to do with freeing up other resources within the U.S. and Europe, whether it's engineering and it's some of the things that ordinarily we would take outside the company into the supply chain. We found that in some of our locus facilities, we can actually produce it ourselves for a lower cost than we can  buy it. And we can continue to be in the systems in those low cost countries, so we don't get the big invoice markup after a three-year contract or whatever with the supplier in a low-cost country. So there's a lot of method to our madness here in driving overall margins across the company.

componenttext: Yes, I would assume about $34 million a quarter for corp. costs and then another $6 million a quarter for other and another $1 million to $2 million for minority interest, which is further below the line. But those are the three elements of nonoperating cost that you probably want to pick up. And that's about $20 million last on the corp side than what we incurred in 2010. And most of that gap is adverse foreign exchange that we experienced in 2010 that we don't expect to recur in 2011 into onetime items that again we don't expect to occur with two week or lack slightly lower comp costs as we go into '11 versus '10. So that's the large part of the gap. The SAP cost of junk a little bit in '11 versus 2010 because we had some large business going live on that system in 2011, the early part, and we'll have some additional support costs as a result. But overall, about $20 million better in 2011 than 2010 on the corp line.

componenttext: I mentioned earlier in response to another question that pension and the benefit of around $0.20, the aftermarket helps us by about 12%. With the two percentage point increase there. Military, while we took out the percentage growth, we really didn't change in the actual dollar growth year-over-year, so no impact from military. And then a slight decrease in the original business, general aviation OE focused on the business just market. So that cost is about $0.05. So the from the prior outlook to the current one is $0.25 to $0.30 better and those three things account for most of it and a little bit higher Corp. cost offset by little better margin performance in our businesses. and that's the GAAP.

But we what we are doing is moving our learning on the manufacturing into those businesses. They're already very good-margin businesses but we think they could even be better. And talked to Scott, he w3ill tell you a little bit outstanding debt a little bit about what we saw in the business jet side. We've kind of lower our forecast on that to kind of lower the smaller air craft. A don't see those coming out of the downturn as fast as the larger jets, the globals and the Gulf streams and so on. There order books are better and they're moving better. So it's really our outlook on the business side more than anything, not on the regionals that we've changed.

componenttext: Well, first of all, other than some cost-plus contracts that are more along the line of ISR, almost all of our contracts are either competitively bid or commercial off-the-shelf pricing, so we don't get the same kind of pressure. Yes, we'll negotiate with it a, another private reselling through to get the business, but we also have the benefit of driving our costs and down through lean and not have to pass it on because it's not a cost-plus contract. So we don't get the same kind of pressure that you would if you were building a total program, a full aircraft program, for instance.

componenttext: And Scott, the tax laws were fairly dramatic in terms of changes in terms of depreciation and some other incentives. And while you provided us with a sense of what the cash flow could be for the upcoming year, how did you think about some of these benefits that would impact you? And does it cause you in any way to think about spending more in the United States than in a low-cost country?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's a couple of points there that what is the changes going forward. The R&D tax credit is obviously helpful, and that's more of a permanent benefit. Some of the accelerated depreciation, bonus depreciation, helps you on the cash flow side, not o
componenttext: I think it's a couple of points there that what is the changes going forward. The R&D tax credit is obviously helpful, and that's more of a permanent benefit. Some of the accelerated depreciation, bonus depreciation, helps you on the cash flow side, not on the earnings side because it's a deferral not a mechanism. When we think about where to put on investment on the margin that does make a difference, for us, it's more important to look at where long-term tax policy is and making those decisions rather than kind of short-term move to how low are those things going to be in place. So if we had more confidence on what the outlook would be two, three, four, five years from now, it would be much more beneficial to our investment philosophy as it relates to U.S. versus elsewhere. And I think a lot of other companies around the industry would look at that as well. It's hard to base your long-term judgments on what happens one year the political wins might go someplace else the following year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And also, if you look at our U.S. investments, I mean, we're expanding our facilitate in Minneapolis area. We're not moving that to a low-cost country. We get very, very good productivity there. We get very good productivity down in our Alabama facilities
componenttext: And also, if you look at our U.S. investments, I mean, we're expanding our facilitate in Minneapolis area. We're not moving that to a low-cost country. We get very, very good productivity there. We get very good productivity down in our Alabama facilities. We've never even considered moving our wheel and brake production out of Ohio because we got a lot of cooperation from that workforce in terms of of lean and we've been able to make that work very well. So it isn't one answer. But I agree with Scott on the tax policy. We need a longer-term tax policy. Look what's going on with this R&D tax credit. I mean, that's just crazy.

componenttext: Well, we haven't seen that big -- I mean, the more out-of-production airplanes, we haven't seen any large jump on that end of the market. We start getting aftermarket on brand new bodies after about one year, beginning with wheels and breaks. And it varies along thereafter. But there's a good wave of those aircraft because we've had very significant deliveries of those narrow bodies in the last five to seven years, which is built up to fleet. And that's why I had said earlier that in spite sort of a stable 4% to 6% ASM outlook, we increased our aftermarket guidance based more on the mix of Goodrich content in the worldwide fleet.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Invest
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Goodrich Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our fourth quarter 2010 results. In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks fol
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our fourth quarter 2010 results. 
In the room with me today are Marshall Larsen, our Chairman, President and CEO; and Scott Kuechle, our CFO. We will start with brief prepared remarks followed by Q&A. A presentation is available at our website, www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release provides the basis for most of our remarks.
Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This call is being webcast. Replays will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon.
Once again, we ask that callers limit themselves to one question so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask your questions. If you have further unanswered questions, please get back into the queue and you can ask another question, time permitting.
Now I'll turn the call over to Marshall, who will provide you with an overview of our fourth quarter results and our outlook for 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. You've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. Today, I'll begin with our fourth quarter results and then turn to our improved earnings outlook for 2011 and discuss its drivers. We closed ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. You've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and the related presentation. Today, I'll begin with our fourth quarter results and then turn to our improved earnings outlook for 2011 and discuss its drivers. 
We closed out a solid 2010 with a very strong fourth quarter results. Our net income per diluted share grew 41% on sales growth of 10%. All of our major market channels, including the commercial aftermarket, reported year-over-year sales growth. Our large commercial airplane original equipment market channel grew by 2%. Our regional, business and general aviation original equipment market, sales increased by about 52%, which included organic growth of about 20%. Commercial aftermarket sales were 12% higher than the fourth quarter last year. Our defense and space sales continued their positive growth trend in the fourth quarter of 2010, increasing by 9% compared to the fourth quarter of 2009. Our acquisition of Atlantic Inertial Systems contributed 7% of this growth, while organic sales growth was about 2%. 
In the fourth quarter 2010, we achieved segment operating income margins of 15.8% compared to 14.2% in the fourth quarter of 2009, which helped us increase our net income per diluted share from $0.82 in the fourth quarter 2009 to $1.16 in the fourth quarter 2010. The overall improvement was due to strong sales growth, excellent operational performance, relentless pursuit of continuous improvement, a lower tax rate and increased favorable changes and estimates for certain long-term contracts, partially offset by costs associated with the early retirement of debt. 
Specifically, as we discussed with you last October, the fourth quarter 2010 results included debt redemption costs of approximately $0.17 per diluted share. We reported an effective tax rate of 8.5% for the fourth quarter 2010 compared to an effective tax rate of 29.5% during the fourth quarter 2009.
Fourth quarter 2010 tax rate included previously announced tax benefit of approximately $0.18 per diluted share related to a settlement with the California Franchise Tax Board concerning issues related to Goodrich and Rohr for all tax years through 2001 and approximately $0.11 per diluted share for the full year 2010 benefit of the R&D tax credit, which was renewed by the U.S. Congress in late 2010.
Our fourth quarter 2010 results included higher pretax income of $8 million, $5 million after tax or $0.04 per diluted share related to changes in estimates for certain long-term contracts, primarily in our Aerostructures and Aircraft Wheels and Brakes businesses compared to the fourth quarter of 2009. 
Total changes in estimates for the fourth quarter 2010 were $27 million pretax. The fourth quarter 2010 included total pretax restructuring charges of $7 million, $4 million after tax or $0.03 per diluted share. These actions were not included in our prior outlook for the 2010 earnings.
Net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures, or free cash flow for the fourth quarter 2010, was a use of cash of $114 million. As we discussed during our last conference call, we made $300 million of incremental contribution to our pension plans in October. Excluding this incremental contribution, our free cash flow conversion of net income would have easily exceeded 100%.
Since last October, we have announced significant progress on existing programs and several new business wins. We have begun environmental testing of the first operationally responsive satellite. We signed a 10-year in a sales service agreement with Air Arabia for the support of missiles and thrust reversers in the airlines' fleet of more than 50 A320 aircraft. 
We were selected by Airbus to provide the main landing gear for the -1000 variant of the A350 XWB aircraft. This contract is expected to generate more than $2 billion in original equipment and aftermath revenue for us over the life of the program. And we received a production contract from Lockheed Martin to supply 160 pylons to the U.S. Air Force C-5  Galaxy strategic airlifter, reliability enhancement and reengining program.
For our full year 2010, we reported a 4% increase in sales to $7 billion, and our income from continuing operations increased from $560 million in 2009 to $577 million in 2010. On a per share basis, we reported income from continuing operations per diluted share of $4.50 in 2010.
For the full year 2010, our large commercial airplane original equipment sales increased by 4%. Regional, business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales grew by 2%, including sales associated with DeCrane acquisition. Organically, sales in this market channel decreased by about 5%. 
Large commercial, regional, business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales were flat compared to 2009. Defense and space sales grew by about 11%, including sales generated by the AIS acquisition. Organic growth in this market channel was 3%.
For 2010, our free cash flow was approximately 50% of income from continuing operations, including the incremental $300 million pension contribution made in the fourth quarter. Excluding this incremental contribution, free cash flow is approximately 102% of income from continuing operations. 
Now I'll turn to 2011. We believe the strong growth trends we experienced in late 2010 will continue in 2011, and we expect significant sales growth in each of our market channels. Overall, we expect sales to grow about 11%, which would provide us with record sales of $7.7 billion to $7.8 billion in 2011. 
Based on the recent improvements in airline capacity trends, improving airline profitability and increasing demand trends for our commercial aftermarket products, we are raising our sales growth expectations for commercial aftermarket sales to a range of 7% to 9%. This strong sales growth should result in an even better growth than net income per diluted share. Largely driven by increased expectations for commercial aftermarket sales and lower pension expense, we now expect 2011 net income per diluted share to be in the range of $5.30 to $5.45, an increase of 18% to 21% compared to 2010.
As I noted, we expect sales growth in 2011 in every market channel, including large commercial airplane original equipment sales growth of about 15%. We are assuming that all announced production rate increases are implemented. And Boeing 787 and 747-8 deliveries are consistent with the latest schedule announced by Boeing. Regional, business and general aviation airplane original equipment sales are expected to grow by about 30%, including incremental sales associated with the DeCrane acquisition. Organically, we expect sales to increase by about 6%.
Large commercial, regional, business and general aviation airplane aftermarket sales are expected to increase by about 7% to 9%. And defense and space sales of both original equipment and aftermarket products and services are expected to increase by about 7% to 9%. 
Our 2011 outlook includes operating margins of about 16.5%. This reflects growth in aftermarket and the benefit of continuous improvement and lean initiatives on costs, offset by very rapid growth in lower-margin commercial original equipment and cost-plus military contracts.
Lower worldwide pretax pension expense of approximately $74 million or $0.37 per diluted share. The estimate for 2011 pension expense is based on the 2010 actual return on U.S. plan assets of 14% and a 2011 U.S. discount rate of 5.67%. In addition, we have reduced our long-term rate of return assumption on U.S. plan assets to 8.25% as of January 1, 2011 compared to our prior assumption of 8.75%. 
For 2011, we expect total worldwide pretax pension expense of approximately $88 million compared to $162 million in 2010. We are expecting a 2011 full year effective tax rate of approximately 30%, somewhat higher than the rate we experienced in 2010. 
We continue to expect net cash provided by operating activities minus capital expenditures to exceed 85% of net income for 2011. Our outlook includes expected capital expenditures of $300 million to $350 million and pretax worldwide pension plan contributions of about $100 million. 
We get a lot of questions about our defense programs and our ability to continue to show significant growth in this market channel. Our defense programs are characterized by diversity and criticality. We are in almost every platform in the defense industry today, both OE and aftermarket. A significant portion of our sales are to international customers, either directly or through foreign military sales contracts. We expect that trend to continue. 
In many cases, we have content on multiple platforms competing for an award, such as the Air Force U.S. tanker competition where we are well positioned on both the Boeing 767 and the Airbus A330. We have strong positions in a number of large defense programs, which will grow over the next several years like the C-5 reengining, the F-35 and the C-130. 
As we have previously discussed in our presentations, we are well positioned in growth markets like helicopters and ISR. We have substantial shipset content on helicopters like the Black Hawk, the Apache and the CH-47. Another area of strength for Goodrich is our ISR sensors. The U2 with our SYERS multi-spectral imaging sensor is being test more than ever, and the Goodrich DB-110 sensor is having great success with numerous international customers and has received new international contract awards.
Finally, we also play a big part in the precision weapons programs of the U.S. and foreign militaries with our actuation and inertial guidance systems. So overall, we feel we are well positioned to help the U.S. and allied troops with vital and cost-effective equipment that will result in continued good growth in our defense and space sales. 
Overall, our performance during the fourth quarter was excellent from an operational standpoint, and we are looking forward to a strong 2011. We continue to expect long-term sustainable growth in sales and earnings fueled by our significant market share gains on new commercial and military aircraft currently in development and steadily increasing commercial aftermarket sales. 
Our financial position remains excellent, with about $800 million of cash on our balance sheet, significant cash flow expectations for 2011 and no significant debt maturities until 2016. This will allow us the flexibility to continue to seek acquisition opportunities that further enhance our sales and earnings growth, contribute to cash generation and drive shareholder value.
I'm looking forward to talking to all of you during 2011. We have a great team, and we're all very excited about continuing to grow the company and our profits as we enter a period of strong commercial aerospace growth. 
With that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we've raised of our aftermarket forecast to the 7% to 9%, Heidi. And as I mentioned in the fourth quarter, we continue to see what we think is a harbinger of better things to come in our Wheel and Brake business where our landings have be
componenttext: Well, obviously, we've raised of our aftermarket forecast to the 7% to 9%, Heidi. And as I mentioned in the fourth quarter, we continue to see what we think is a harbinger of better things to come in our Wheel and Brake business where our landings have been steadily increasing. And we were starting off January in many of our businesses with a much larger backlog than we had in January of last year. So orders are coming in. And particularly in our Aerostructures business, the orders from majors have turned up in the fourth quarter. That's a very good sign that airlines are having to do some restocking on parts that they have avoided buying in the past because they've had a lot of spare engines out there. So it's not any one thing, we're just kind of seeing a lot of our aftermarket businesses see a much better level of activity, which gave us the confidence to raise that forecast.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I'm jumping between various calls this morning so you may have addressed this a little bit. But could you talk about the moving pieces of the revenue guidance? You just mentioned you took aftermarket up, but a couple of other things went down.
componenttext: Marshall, I'm jumping between various calls this morning so you may have addressed this a little bit. But could you talk about the moving pieces of the revenue guidance? You just mentioned you took aftermarket up, but a couple of other things went down.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We thought you'd ask that question. So my colleague is here and always prepared. Yes, and in terms of the military side, we changed the guidance in terms of growth rates, but the absolute dollars for 2011 are pretty similar to what we would have expected
componenttext: We thought you'd ask that question. So my colleague is here and always prepared. Yes, and in terms of the military side, we changed the guidance in terms of growth rates, but the absolute dollars for 2011 are pretty similar to what we would have expected back in October. So we had a little bit softer sales level in the fourth quarter of 2010. But if you look at the dollar sales value in 2011, that's fairly unchanged. So the only other market segment that we changed a bit was regional, business, general aviation, where we took those sales down by around $50 million from our prior guidance. That's mostly in the business jet market. And just to give you a little bit of color there, first of all, it's a relatively small part of our total sales, 4%, 5% when you look at OE and aftermarket. So it's not a huge part of our business. But we're seeing good underlying trends that would suggest momentum in that marketplace is starting to develop. So the things that we look for are the used aircraft prices beginning to stabilize. We're seeing better activity levels across the current business jet fleet, and we're seeing good growth in Goodrich's aftermarket related to the business jets. And what we're seeing on the OE side there is decent expectations for growth in OE sales rates, production rates on the larger aircraft. But the smaller, small and midsized aircraft have not yet seen those kinds of increases. So our general view is the small and medium growth rates are pushed out to 2012 from where we were thinking they could occur in the second half of '11, previously. So that's the major change in our sales guidance there. And on commercial OE, we took those down from a range of 15% to 20% growth in October down to 15%, and that's all related to changed expectations on 787.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just one last question on airline maintenance, have you noticed any behavior change back toward normal from the airlines. Through the recession, they were very tight on how they did maintenance? Everything was done at the last minute. Anything that co
componenttext: And just one last question on airline maintenance, have you noticed any behavior change back toward normal from the airlines. Through the recession, they were very tight on how they did maintenance? Everything was done at the last minute. Anything that could be put off was put off, cannibalizing parts, all that sort of thing. Have you seen any loosening?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the biggest indicator is the majors on Aerostructures, the[indiscernible], the thrust reversers and things like that. They are high-dollar items that they -- and they really were avoiding doing because they had aircraft that weren't being ut
componenttext: Well, I think the biggest indicator is the majors on Aerostructures, the[indiscernible], the thrust reversers and things like that. They are high-dollar items that they -- and they really were avoiding doing because they had aircraft that weren't being utilized as heavily. And I think that's an indicator to us between that. And the backlog on our Wheel and Brake business and the increased landings indicate to me that their getting towards the end of the rope in terms of having to restock.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So that being the case, your 12% in the quarter, you're guiding lower than that for the year, so just the higher -- the more difficult comps going forward?
componenttext: So that being the case, your 12% in the quarter, you're guiding lower than that for the year, so just the higher -- the more difficult comps going forward?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right.
componenttext: Yes, that's right.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs has our next question.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Juts following up on some of your answers to Heidi's questions. I think last quarter, you specifically said you were looking for the majors to be flat in '11 and also we're not looking for much price. Can you just quantify how much different those are in
componenttext: Juts following up on some of your answers to Heidi's questions. I think last quarter, you specifically said you were looking for the majors to be flat in '11 and also we're not looking for much price. Can you just quantify how much different those are in the new outlook? And I think you just also stated, just for clarification, that order activity in January was accelerated versus the fourth quarter. Is that correct?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I said the backlog is higher in January going into January than it was going into January of 2009. So I mean, that's a good sign. And on the majors, a few months is hard to make a trend out of it, but it's a very good sign that we're moving back towards n
componenttext: I said the backlog is higher in January going into January than it was going into January of 2009. So I mean, that's a good sign. And on the majors, a few months is hard to make a trend out of it, but it's a very good sign that we're moving back towards normal levels on major orders. So we're in a lot better shape in January of this year on major orders that we were last year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And any new thoughts on price for the year?
componenttext: And any new thoughts on price for the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll get price increases in selected areas, but we're also taking advantage of trying to grab market share, too.
componenttext: We'll get price increases in selected areas, but we're also taking advantage of trying to grab market share, too.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Scott, would you be willing to share with us what you're looking for the operating margins in the three different segments in '11?
componenttext: And Scott, would you be willing to share with us what you're looking for the operating margins in the three different segments in '11?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We can give you some rough ranges. I mean, we've talked about overall margins across the enterprise at about 16.5%, give or take, in 2011. So our expectations generally by segment would be in the 11% to 12% range in actuation and landing systems; 21% to 2
componenttext: We can give you some rough ranges. I mean, we've talked about overall margins across the enterprise at about 16.5%, give or take, in 2011. So our expectations generally by segment would be in the 11% to 12% range in actuation and landing systems; 21% to 22% in nacelle; and 16 to 17% in electronics. And that would get you to about 16.5%. And again, everyone of those can move by 0.5 pretty easily during the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Robert Stallard with Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Robert Stallard with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on those operating margins, Scott, if I could. I was wondering if you could give us some of the puts and takes for why specifically you think that sales have been coming down year-on-year, especially given these positive aftermark
componenttext: I just want to follow up on those operating margins, Scott, if I could. I was wondering if you could give us some of the puts and takes for why specifically you think that sales have been coming down year-on-year, especially given these positive aftermarket trends?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, you get positive aftermarket, but we're getting a lot of OE growth in that particular business. So 787 sales will be much higher in 2011 than they are in '10. And those are low margin to no margin for new programs coming out of the block. So for the
componenttext: Well, you get positive aftermarket, but we're getting a lot of OE growth in that particular business. So 787 sales will be much higher in 2011 than they are in '10. And those are low margin to no margin for new programs coming out of the block. So for them, it's in part a mix issue. And then secondly, we do expect lower levels of contract adjustments in 2011 than we did in 2010. And the offset then obviously is a much better aftermarket environment, which is good margin, so it offsets a lot of that change.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I assume this is the case of the first two aerospace-driven divisions. But you probably have this dilutive issue of 787 being more back-end loaded than first-half loaded?
componenttext: I assume this is the case of the first two aerospace-driven divisions. But you probably have this dilutive issue of 787 being more back-end loaded than first-half loaded?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that. I think that's relatively steady throughout the year.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that. I think that's relatively steady throughout the year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it depends on the business because -- we're still delivering on a lot of things here in the first half of the year that they haven't showed us down on.
componenttext: Yes, it depends on the business because -- we're still delivering on a lot of things here in the first half of the year that they haven't showed us down on.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify, you're aftermarket, sequentially, commercial aftermarket was down 2%, sequentially. Is there anything to read into that?
componenttext: And just to clarify, you're aftermarket, sequentially, commercial aftermarket was down 2%, sequentially. Is there anything to read into that?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, nothing there. I mean, fourth quarter is generally a weaker quarter because of the utilization of the passenger airline or package airlines trying to run everything all out. So that we don't read anything into it. What we took heart in is that the ord
componenttext: No, nothing there. I mean, fourth quarter is generally a weaker quarter because of the utilization of the passenger airline or package airlines trying to run everything all out. So that we don't read anything into it. What we took heart in is that the order intake during that time period was better than we've had in the past.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll hear from George Shapiro with Access 342.
componenttext: Next, we'll hear from George Shapiro with Access 342.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: In actuation, even if you make the adjustment for like the $4 million last pickup this year, the margin would have been about flat. And yet you had lower defense and higher aftermarket, which I think -- actually think would have been a favorable mix so I
componenttext: In actuation, even if you make the adjustment for like the $4 million last pickup this year, the margin would have been about flat. And yet you had lower defense and higher aftermarket, which I think -- actually think would have been a favorable mix so I would have expected the margin to be a little bit higher then. So maybe, Scott, if you can just go through what's wrong with that thinking?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: George, just referring to fourth quarter margins or...
componenttext: George, just referring to fourth quarter margins or...

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm just looking at the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Yes. I'm just looking at the fourth quarter.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, there are a few higher cost items in the fourth quarter. We booked about $3 million or so of restructuring costs in the quarter in compensation cost. Generally, we're higher at the corp G&A than  our normal levels, and that was probably $6 mill
componenttext: Okay. Yes, there are a few higher cost items in the fourth quarter. We booked about $3 million or so of restructuring costs in the quarter in compensation cost. Generally, we're higher at the corp G&A than  our normal levels, and that was probably $6 million, $7 million. And each segment had higher comp cost as well in the $2 million, $3 million range per segment. So between those two, there's $5 million to $6 million of cost in the fourth quarter that aren't theare on a normal basis, so that's almost the point of margin right there. And then as Marshall said, we ended the quarter with a decent backlog in the Wheel and Brake business. So there was timing of shipments that moved from fourth quarter to first quarter of 2011 that changed that margin picture in the fourth quarter just a little bit. So those three factors are mostly the gap between our normal margin levels of a little over 11% to where they were in the fourth quarter of about 10%.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also if you just comment, you mentioned this higher operating costs with landing gear, wheels and brakes, and just what that -- a little more color on what that meant?
componenttext: Okay. And then also if you just comment, you mentioned this higher operating costs with landing gear, wheels and brakes, and just what that -- a little more color on what that meant?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It was really what I was referring to earlier, those items.
componenttext: It was really what I was referring to earlier, those items.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And now we'll go to Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: And now we'll go to Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of bookkeeping questions. Can you just talk a little bit about what the restructuring was all about? And then in one of the slides, you've got some benefit that you expect in 2011 related to foreign exchange. Can you talk a little bit about what
componenttext: A couple of bookkeeping questions. Can you just talk a little bit about what the restructuring was all about? And then in one of the slides, you've got some benefit that you expect in 2011 related to foreign exchange. Can you talk a little bit about what that's coming from and what the volatility might be there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, restructuring, those are just relatively small facility consolidation restructuring that we had expected to do sometime in 2011 or even 2012. And frankly, with the benefit of the R&D tax credit and some of the other upsides we saw, we decide
componenttext: Sure. I mean, restructuring, those are just relatively small facility consolidation restructuring that we had expected to do sometime in 2011 or even 2012. And frankly, with the benefit of the R&D tax credit and some of the other upsides we saw, we decided to pull those in a little bit faster, start those activities sooner and get the benefits sooner as well. So there were just two different facilities that we looked at there. On the foreign exchange side, what we're looking at there in 2011 is about $20 million benefit versus 2010 in terms of foreign exchange exposure and hedge cost in 2011 versus '10. And we're about 93% hedged going into 2011, so there shouldn't be a lot of volatility around that number. And then when we look forward into 2012, we could see an additional $25 million benefit on top of the benefit we have in 201, if exchange rates stay about where they are today. And we're about 73% hedged in 2012. And then we're about 60% hedged in 2013. And there'll be a modest benefit in addition in 2013 over 2012, but it's in the $2 million to $5 million range.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then CapEx expectations going out beyond '11, did they going to go much above that $300 million to $350 million?
componenttext: And then CapEx expectations going out beyond '11, did they going to go much above that $300 million to $350 million?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't expect them to go above the $300 million to $350 million, but they might stay at an elevated level for the next couple of years because we are continuing to invest in some of our low-cost country to drive margins in the future. And we also have
componenttext: I wouldn't expect them to go above the $300 million to $350 million, but they might stay at an elevated level for the next couple of years because we are continuing to invest in some of our low-cost country to drive margins in the future. And we also have some raised [ph] capital that we'll be spending to keep up with the production rate increases that the OEs have announced. Get ready for A350s, 787 ramp up, et cetera.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to start out on DeCrane, it looks like you took down your sales expectations there from the high 100s to the low 100s? And I know you mentioned some of the business jet outlook has or some of the small and midsized have been pushed out. But is ther
componenttext: I want to start out on DeCrane, it looks like you took down your sales expectations there from the high 100s to the low 100s? And I know you mentioned some of the business jet outlook has or some of the small and midsized have been pushed out. But is there anything else going on there? Because it looks like the sales expectations came down by close to a third.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, that's anywhere near that kind of a magnitude. We had expected sales growth in that business, and we're expecting that to be more stable in 2011 versus their run rate in 2010. It's driven by the changed expectation on when we'll start to see OE growth
componenttext: No, that's anywhere near that kind of a magnitude. We had expected sales growth in that business, and we're expecting that to be more stable in 2011 versus their run rate in 2010. It's driven by the changed expectation on when we'll start to see OE growth occur in the OE production rate increases in the small and medium-sized end of that market.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'd have to go back and check my numbers. But since you raised the organic growth outlook and lowered the overall sales outlook for the business, and maybe depends on the 2009 comp, that could throw me off [ph]. Okay. Can you comment on AIS? And
componenttext: I guess, I'd have to go back and check my numbers. But since you raised the organic growth outlook and lowered the overall sales outlook for the business, and maybe depends on the 2009 comp, that could throw me off [ph]. Okay. Can you comment on AIS? And you mentioned some higher operating costs there. Is that just expected restructuring? Or is there something else going on there as well?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's just the way we do the GAAP when we report the MD&A. The additional SG&A and nonrecurring engineering costs just show up as additional costs because the volume and mix on that has picked up in the other lines. So it's not higher costs than what the
componenttext: That's just the way we do the GAAP when we report the MD&A. The additional SG&A and nonrecurring engineering costs just show up as additional costs because the volume and mix on that has picked up in the other lines. So it's not higher costs than what the business was incurring, it's just that we didn't have those costs a year ago.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, how is the acquisition going?
componenttext: Well, how is the acquisition going?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: AIS is going very well. We've been very pleased with the people, the technology, the ability to access markets, both in the U.S. and outside the U.S. because that is a U.K. business. So they've got some very exciting opportunities. They continue to win bu
componenttext: AIS is going very well. We've been very pleased with the people, the technology, the ability to access markets, both in the U.S. and outside the U.S. because that is a U.K. business. So they've got some very exciting opportunities. They continue to win business at the rate that we expected relative to the competition. So we're very pleased with that business.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Scott, can you walk us through 2010, the 2011 in terms of the increase in the guidance? I've looked at the earnings bridge today versus last time and there are some things that are not included at this time. They were included last time. But just thinking
componenttext: Scott, can you walk us through 2010, the 2011 in terms of the increase in the guidance? I've looked at the earnings bridge today versus last time and there are some things that are not included at this time. They were included last time. But just thinking about it, you got $0.22 from pension. I know that's $0.15 to $0.20 from the higher aftermarket. I know your contract adjustments are now off of a bigger number from 2010, but it looks like that actually, got pumped up on an absolute basis. So I'm just trying to reconcile all that with the guidance only moving up $0.20 to $0.30.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you're not talking about '10 to '11, you're talking about prior guidance to current guidance?
componenttext: So you're not talking about '10 to '11, you're talking about prior guidance to current guidance?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, I guess. I mean, I guess my starting point is just you got $0.22 from pension and upside versus what you were thinking before and you got another, based on your numbers, it looks like $0.19 on the aftermarket. So I'm trying to figure out the off
componenttext: Yes. Yes, I guess. I mean, I guess my starting point is just you got $0.22 from pension and upside versus what you were thinking before and you got another, based on your numbers, it looks like $0.19 on the aftermarket. So I'm trying to figure out the offsets to reconcile to the only $0.25 to $0.30 increase in guidance.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, like you said, we upped our guidance by $0.25 to $0.30. So the big factors are pension, and as mentioned, which is about a $0.21, $0.22 benefit. I mean, I would point out that not all of that pension expense reduction actually flow through earn
componenttext: Okay. Yes, like you said, we upped our guidance by $0.25 to $0.30. So the big factors are pension, and as mentioned, which is about a $0.21, $0.22 benefit. I mean, I would point out that not all of that pension expense reduction actually flow through earnings in 2011 because some of it gets caught up in inventory and some it is already reflected in our contracts, but just assuming that, that's about $0.20. Aftermarket sales, we took our guidance up by two percentage points, and we've said about $0.06 per share per percentage point and growth. So that's about $0.12 of increase there. And then the offset would be the slight reduction in sales in RBG&A OE, so the business jet OE market that we spoke of a moment ago. And then we do have expectation for a little bit higher corp cost in 2011 than we did earlier, and that's frankly all due to the higher stock price that we're enjoying. So then whatever else the gap is, a couple of cents is operational performance on the margin line.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if I'm reading the contract adjustments right, it looks like just on an absolute basis, you're now expecting like $35 million to $40 million in positive contract adjustments in 2011?
componenttext: And if I'm reading the contract adjustments right, it looks like just on an absolute basis, you're now expecting like $35 million to $40 million in positive contract adjustments in 2011?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our expectation is kind of $25 million, $35 million, in that range, contract adjustment next year. And that's really not a change from where we were earlier.
componenttext: Our expectation is kind of $25 million, $35 million, in that range, contract adjustment next year. And that's really not a change from where we were earlier.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: And last one for me, timing on a decision on A320 NEO nacelle?
