headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone and welcome to the Goodrich First Quarter 2011 Earnings Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Vice Pres
componenttext: Good day, everyone and welcome to the Goodrich First Quarter 2011 Earnings Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations Mr. Paul Gifford. Please go ahead, Sir.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Glenn and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter 2011 results. In the room with me today is Scott Kuechle, our CFO. Marshall Larsen is on the call and he is at a different Goodrich facility at this point so be patient wi
componenttext:
Thank you, Glenn and thank you for joining us today as we discuss our first quarter 2011 results. In the room with me today is Scott Kuechle, our CFO. Marshall Larsen is on the call and he is at a different Goodrich facility at this point so be patient with us please as our hand offs in the Q&A session may be a little slower than usual. We will start with brief preferred remarks followed by Q&A. A presentation is available at our website, www.goodrich.com, which together with our press release, provides the basis for most of our remarks. 
Before we start, let me remind you that today's remarks include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties and that actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. The risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. They are also detailed in today's earnings press release. I urge you to read them carefully. This conference call is being webcast and a replay will be available at our Internet site beginning this afternoon. Once again, we ask that callers limit themselves to one question so that we can have time to allow all of you to ask questions. If you have further unanswered questions, you can get back into the queue and ask another question, time permitting. Now, I'll turn the call over to Marshall who will provide you with an overview of our first quarter 2011 results and our updated outlook for 2011.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. You've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and a related presentation. Today, I'll begin with our first quarter results and then turn to our updated outlook for 2011 and discuss its drivers. We started out 2011 with ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. You've all had the opportunity to review today's earnings release and a related presentation. Today, I'll begin with our first quarter results and then turn to our updated outlook for 2011 and discuss its drivers. We started out 2011 with excellent first quarter results. Our net income per diluted share grew 75% on sales growth of 12%. All of our major market channels, including the commercial aftermarket, reported year-over-year and sequential sales growth. On a year-over-year basis, our large commercial airplane original equipment market channel grew by 6%. Our original business and General Aviation original equipment sales increased by about 55%, which included sales associated with last year's DeCrane acquisition. Our commercial aftermarket sales growth of 12% was significantly greater than the growth in the airline capacity and slightly higher than our expectations and helped solidify our view that 2011 will be a strong growth year for this channel. The first quarter 2011 sales were 9% higher than fourth quarter 2010. Our defense and space sales grew organically at a double-digit rate. We believe that our presence in attractive, high-growth markets such as ISR, helicopters and precision munitions will enable Goodrich to grow our defense and space sales faster than the global defense budgets over the next several years. In the first quarter 2011, we achieved segment operating income margins of 17.7% compared to 15.3% in the first quarter 2010, which helped us increase our net income per diluted share to $1.52 in the first quarter 2011 from $0.87 in the first quarter 2010. The overall margin improvement was primarily due to strong growth in aftermarket defense and regional business and general aviation sales, excellent operational performance, relentless pursuit of continued improvement and lower pension expense. EPS also benefited from a lower tax rate. Regarding taxes, we reported an effective tax rate of 24.4% for the first quarter 2011 compared to an effective tax rate of 37.9% during the first quarter 2010. The first quarter 2011 tax rate includes a previously announced benefit of approximately $20 million or $0.16 per diluted share related to a tax settlement. There were no similar benefits during the first quarter 2010. Last year, in the first quarter, we had an additional tax expense of $10 million or $0.08 per diluted share for the U.S. healthcare reform legislation, which was not repeated this year. We continue to expect the full tax year to be about 30%. The benefit in the first quarter versus the average rate of 30% was about $0.11 per share. Compared to last year, we had a lower pretax pension expense of about $21 million or $0.10 per diluted share in the first quarter 2011. Total changes and estimates for the first quarter 2011 were $21 million pretax, slightly better than the $16 million we reported in the first quarter 2010. Net cash provided by operating activities, minus capital expenditures or free cash flow for the first quarter 2011 was $61 million, a $52 million improvement over the results for the first quarter 2011. During the quarter, we completed most of our planned pension contributions for the year. Since last February, we have now several business highlights. We announced an agreement to acquire Microtecnica, a leading provider of flight control actuation systems for helicopters, regional business, aircraft and missile actuation. The business also provides thermal and environmental control systems for commercial and military aircraft. We expect this acquisition to close during the second quarter 2011. We were selected by Airbus to provide the nacelle system for the Pratt & Whitney PurePower 1100G engine, one of the engine options on the Airbus A320neo, new engine option airplane. We were awarded the contract to deliver two upgraded Senior Year Electro-Optical Reconnaissance Sensors, SYERS, to the United States Air Force for use on the U-2 platform. We completed the certification process for the Boeing 787 electric braking system and we received a follow-on contract from the Defense Logistics Agency to supply over 1,600 carbon brakes and over 1,400 boltless wheels for the U.S. Air Force C-130 aircraft fleet. 
Now, I'll turn to our expectations for the full year 2011. We believe the strong growth trends we experienced in the first quarter 2011 will continue throughout 2011 and we expect significant sales growth in each of our major market channels. Overall, we expect sales to grow about 12%, which will provide us with sales of approximately $7.8 billion in 2011, at the top end of our prior outlook. Our new outlook does not include sales associated with the Microtecnica acquisition. We will update our sales outlook when we report our quarterly results for the quarter in which the acquisition closes. While aftermarket sales in the first quarter were a little stronger than we expected, airline capacity growth remains consistent with our forecast, so we are maintaining our 7% to 9% sales growth expectations for the commercial aftermarket sales for 2011. Our expectations for growth in defense and space market channel increased to 8% to 10% based on our strong first quarter sales and based on business we already have in hand and expectations for future awards, especially in our intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance business. This strong sales growth should result in even better growth in net income per diluted share. We now expect 2011 net income per diluted share to be in the range of $5.40 to $5.55, an increase of 20% to 23% compared to 2010. As usual, our outlook does not include restructuring charges for actions that have not yet been approved or announced. On March 14, 2011, our Landing Gear business began discussions with one of its local employee units regarding a new contract. The contract expires in May 2011. Our discussions included the fact that we are considering the potential closure of our Landing Gear business in Cleveland, Ohio and negotiations with the union are ongoing. Should we decide to close the facility, we would likely need to recognize personnel-related and facility closure costs at that time. 
Our 2011 outlook includes operating margins of about 16.5% to 17%. This reflects growth in the aftermarket, the benefit of continuous improvement and lean initiatives on costs and lower pension expense, partially offset by very rapid growth in lower margin, commercial original equipment and cost plus military contracts, lower worldwide prepension expense of approximately $74 million or $0.37 per diluted share. This is unchanged from our prior outlook. 
We are expecting a 2011 full year effective tax rate of approximately 30%, somewhat higher than the rate we experienced in 2011. The remaining three quarters of 2011, our quarterly effective tax rate should average around 32%. We continue to expect net cash provided by operating activities, minus capital expenditures, to exceed 85% of net income for 2011. Our outlook includes expected capital expenditures of $300 million to $350 million and pretax worldwide pension expense -- pardon me, worldwide pension planned contributions of about $100 million. Overall, our performance during the first quarter was excellent from an operational standpoint and is a building block towards a very strong 2011. We continue to expect long-term sustainable growth in sales and earnings fueled by strong market conditions in commercial original equipment and aftermarket, our significant market share gains on new commercial military aircraft currently in development and our position in growth areas of military budgets, helicopters, precision-guided munitions, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance and fixed wing aircraft retrofit programs. 
Our financial position remains excellent, with about $800 million of cash on our balance sheet, significant cash flow expectations for 2011 and no significant debt maturities until 2016. This will allow us the flexibility to continue to seek additional acquisition opportunities that further enhance our sales and earnings growth, contribute to cash generation and drive shareholder value. I'm looking forward to talking to all of you during the remainder of 2011. We have a great team and we are all very excited about continuing growth in our company and our profits as we enter a period of strong commercial aerospace growth. Let's now open the call to questions.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Robert Spingarn from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Robert Spingarn from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marshall, could you talk a little bit about with regard to the aftermarket, the sensitivity to fuel and then at what point your 7% to 9% target might be risk, understanding that you outperformed that here in the first quarter?
componenttext: Marshall, could you talk a little bit about with regard to the aftermarket, the sensitivity to fuel and then at what point your 7% to 9% target might be risk, understanding that you outperformed that here in the first quarter?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rob. First of all, we've had no effect really. I don't think from that fuel increase issue at this point in time. Generally, it's a lag effect of six months or more. But where we see it mostly is here in the U.S. You've seen some of the airlines lik
componenttext: Sure, Rob. First of all, we've had no effect really. I don't think from that fuel increase issue at this point in time. Generally, it's a lag effect of six months or more. But where we see it mostly is here in the U.S. You've seen some of the airlines like Delta reduce their capacity increases that they were planning. But we've also seen offsets in Asia and particularly where we've seen a lot more activity on the ASM side. So I'm not very concerned that we're not going to be able to hit our aftermarket forecast for the year. You just take what we gained in the first quarter and project it through year end, we'd be at the top end of that 7% to 9% range. So although we're watching the situation, we think we can still deliver that kind of growth.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just briefly, it's a distant question, I suppose, but on the Neo, could you talk about any content difference for you on that airplane and how we should think about margins as that ramps a few years from now? Relative to what you're doing with the A32
componenttext: And just briefly, it's a distant question, I suppose, but on the Neo, could you talk about any content difference for you on that airplane and how we should think about margins as that ramps a few years from now? Relative to what you're doing with the A320 classic? That's an OE question, Marshall.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: An OE question? Okay. It will start out probably a little bit lower margin. But we will end up getting it right back to where we were on the other. And that's just going through the learning curve. And it takes a little time there but given that particula
componenttext: An OE question? Okay. It will start out probably a little bit lower margin. But we will end up getting it right back to where we were on the other. And that's just going through the learning curve. And it takes a little time there but given that particular unit's ability to deal with that kind of product and leaning it out, I'm fairly confident we'll get there fairly quickly.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And on the revenue content?
componenttext: And on the revenue content?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Revenue content should not be an issue. I think we will do equally as well, if not better.
componenttext: Revenue content should not be an issue. I think we will do equally as well, if not better.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Troy O'Leary with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: We'll go next to Troy O'Leary with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about some of the favorable contract adjustments that I think you were forecasting $25 million to $35 million. Is that still what you're tracking for the year or do you see more upside to that?
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about some of the favorable contract adjustments that I think you were forecasting $25 million to $35 million. Is that still what you're tracking for the year or do you see more upside to that?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Troy, this is Scott. Yes, I think our view is we would have a little bit upside to that initial number. We said $25 million to $35 million when we came into the year. I think based on what we saw in the first quarter, we take that up about $10 million, to
componenttext: Troy, this is Scott. Yes, I think our view is we would have a little bit upside to that initial number. We said $25 million to $35 million when we came into the year. I think based on what we saw in the first quarter, we take that up about $10 million, to the $35 million to $45 million range. The performance in the first quarter was driven by the same things that we've seen over the last several years, largely on the cost side where we continue to drive improvements in productivity. The supply chain continues to deliver favorable results et cetera. So good operational performance that continues to be reflected in those numbers. Also, good on the overhead side where we continue to benefit from rising rates throughout the commercial sector and that helps us with overhead absorption. So good trends, nothing dramatically different. Some of the wheel and brakes performance improvements in the first quarter were expected for the full year. So there's a little bit of a phasing there. So not all of the Delta between the average rate for the full year versus what we saw in the first quarter it's all incremental upside. Some of it is just timing.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: By the actual $10 million, that's mostly spread throughout the segments or the actual upside kind of one particular area?
componenttext: By the actual $10 million, that's mostly spread throughout the segments or the actual upside kind of one particular area?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I'd say it's more concentrated for the overall year-to-year improvement. I would say the actuation benefit, which was about $6 million in total dollars in the quarter is more timing.
componenttext: No. I'd say it's more concentrated for the overall year-to-year improvement. I would say the actuation benefit, which was about $6 million in total dollars in the quarter is more timing.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Herbert with Wedbush.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Herbert with Wedbush.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up with another question on the aftermarkets. I know you've talked a lot about this, how the cycle's obviously different for the reasons you've talked about, Marshall, in the past. But how would you say your confidence now in the aft
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up with another question on the aftermarkets. I know you've talked a lot about this, how the cycle's obviously different for the reasons you've talked about, Marshall, in the past. But how would you say your confidence now in the aftermarket recovery may compare relative to the last cycle when you were able to consistently outperform guidance fairly significantly? Do you think this cycle, there is really -- you're sensing a lot more caution now in terms of your outlook or are you sensing similar amount of confidence relative to the last cycle in terms of the performance we should expect?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think as we progress on this cycle because if you think about where we're getting the benefit of the OE build rates, which helps other areas of our company, but on the aftermarket, there is no reason to believe that we will perform any differently going
componenttext: I think as we progress on this cycle because if you think about where we're getting the benefit of the OE build rates, which helps other areas of our company, but on the aftermarket, there is no reason to believe that we will perform any differently going forward. I think we're still in an aftermarket transition. '09 was down, '10, we were transitioning. I expect '11 to be stronger and I think we will start hitting the stride out there in the aftermarket with the airlines in '12 and '13. I just think we're still in that transition at this point in time. And as we said in the first quarter, our aftermarket versus last year was up 12% and it was up over and above ASKs and ASMs.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And sequentially it seemed a little bit stronger. One quick follow up, are you starting to hear from many customers any concern about or any interest and perhaps now, not necessarily restocking that starting to see more confidence from the customers in pe
componenttext: And sequentially it seemed a little bit stronger. One quick follow up, are you starting to hear from many customers any concern about or any interest and perhaps now, not necessarily restocking that starting to see more confidence from the customers in perhaps carrying excess inventory, which certainly was pushed off significantly obviously last year and in the early part of this year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I wouldn't say we're at a point where they're trying to carry excess inventory. I think they're still watching cash, particularly the U.S. carriers. But what we're seeing is greater orders. An example, in our Interiors business, which you could say
componenttext: Well, I wouldn't say we're at a point where they're trying to carry excess inventory. I think they're still watching cash, particularly the U.S. carriers. But what we're seeing is greater orders. An example, in our Interiors business, which you could say is more discretionary than our other businesses, our book to bill is up significantly from last year. That indicates to me that they're willing to spend money at this point in time, not just on flight critical items.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Very good. Thank you very much.
componenttext: Very good. Thank you very much.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about on the margins and in particular, Electronic Systems? Just looking from the December quarter to the March quarter, you have profits up about $19 million but sales only up about $12 million and year-over-year, something like
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about on the margins and in particular, Electronic Systems? Just looking from the December quarter to the March quarter, you have profits up about $19 million but sales only up about $12 million and year-over-year, something like a 70% incremental margin? So just why was that so strong and in general, it seems like the guidance implies lower margins for all three segments for the remainder of the year? So I'm just trying to think about what could cause that?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Scott, what caused that to happen?
componenttext: Scott, what caused that to happen?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sam, just kind of on the general question regarding margins are likely to go in the second or the last three quarters of the year. We were projecting 16.5% to 17% margins for the full year and we started off the first quarter at 17.7%. What we're going to
componenttext: Sam, just kind of on the general question regarding margins are likely to go in the second or the last three quarters of the year. We were projecting 16.5% to 17% margins for the full year and we started off the first quarter at 17.7%. What we're going to in see the next three quarters is a pretty significant ramp up on OE sales, which as you know, are somewhat dilutive to margins. We would expect the last three quarters to operate at about 10% higher than the run rate in the first quarter from an OE sales standpoint. So that will be a little bit dilutive to margins. And also, some of the cost plus military programs continue to ramp throughout the year. So both of those things put a little bit of downward pressure on margins. And in addition, our wheel and brake business puts out more low charge hardware as rates ramp up on the OE side. So those two things will put a little bit of downward pressure on margins. Relative to Electronic Systems, some of that was just a comparable point a year ago. They had some unusual one-time costs in the year-ago period first quarter 2010 that are no longer part of the process. They finished up -- and if you look sequentially as well, they had some unusual charges in the fourth quarter of last year as well, including finishing up some of the R&D work on 787 in the fuels area, which will relieve some of that cost going forward as well. So the run rate for that business, our expectations for full year '11 are in the 16% to 17% range. So the first quarter at 16.4% is very consistent with what we expect for the full year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And if I can just follow-up with a question of the aftermarket. If I just back into what the dollars were based on the first quarter, it would seem that the dollars of sales to the commercial aftermarket, the state of the current level for the
componenttext: Thank you. And if I can just follow-up with a question of the aftermarket. If I just back into what the dollars were based on the first quarter, it would seem that the dollars of sales to the commercial aftermarket, the state of the current level for the first quarter throughout the year, you would exceed your 7% to 9% growth rate. So is there a reason to think the dollars of sales would actually decline as we look forward into the year?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sam, you did the math right. The view is that first quarter aftermarket results continue to hold sequentially for the rest of the year, we'd be right at the top end of our guidance range of 7% to 9%. And we haven't seen anything that would indicate declin
componenttext: Sam, you did the math right. The view is that first quarter aftermarket results continue to hold sequentially for the rest of the year, we'd be right at the top end of our guidance range of 7% to 9%. And we haven't seen anything that would indicate declines based on what's happened around the world relative to oil and other disruptions. So and the top end of our guidance, with the top end of that aftermarket range. So if things sequentially go better than that, that would provide some upside to our forecast. We're just being a little bit cautious given the uncertainty that is out there. But we've seen nothing that would say that it wouldn't, that it couldn't be better.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Robert Stallard with Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: We'll go next to Robert Stallard with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I was wondering if you could comment on a couple of things on the supply chain, your supply chain. First of all, you see any impact from the issues in Japan? And secondly, on a more broader issue, how comfortable or you that your supply chain is
componenttext: Marshall, I was wondering if you could comment on a couple of things on the supply chain, your supply chain. First of all, you see any impact from the issues in Japan? And secondly, on a more broader issue, how comfortable or you that your supply chain is ready to deal with the OEM ramp up you're talking about?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, starting with the tragic events that happened in Japan, all our suppliers there are safe and operating and we're continuously monitoring their status. The biggest issue is whether power or transportation shortages continue. We've had no issues right
componenttext: Well, starting with the tragic events that happened in Japan, all our suppliers there are safe and operating and we're continuously monitoring their status. The biggest issue is whether power or transportation shortages continue. We've had no issues right now with it. A little concerned about air shipping capacity as more products flown in and out of Japan. But right now, our rates are holding up with this. So bottom line, we've got no detrimental impact to date. But situation, based on the power, at least, remains a little bit dynamic. But we've got enough inventory at critical parts of our business to sustain us for the next few months. So I'm not too worried about that. The second question on our supply chain broadly, that's something we spend a lot of time with. As we've gone through the continuous improvement journey at Goodrich, you end up not just trying to lean at your natural facilities but you go into your key suppliers to do the same things. A lot of times, that means small suppliers that don't have the staff to do that kind of thing. And so we'll send people in and help them improve their on-time deliveries and quality. We get a benefit by that and many times, we can actually get a lower price. So I think we're sitting pretty well for the ramp up from our supply base.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just coming at I guess the guidance a different way, if you exclude the tax gain in the quarter, the lower tax rate in the quarter, you're around $1.41. You're going to have based on your guidance for sales, your sales are going to be a little bit higher
componenttext: Just coming at I guess the guidance a different way, if you exclude the tax gain in the quarter, the lower tax rate in the quarter, you're around $1.41. You're going to have based on your guidance for sales, your sales are going to be a little bit higher sequentially from here, yet if you take $1.40 and multiply it by 40 or above the top end of the range, am I missing anything in that math?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, I think the only thing you're missing is the contract adjustments. We're a little higher in the first quarter than what we were expecting for the full year. So that would take a little bit of that up. Then also, as you get more OE shipments in the
componenttext: David, I think the only thing you're missing is the contract adjustments. We're a little higher in the first quarter than what we were expecting for the full year. So that would take a little bit of that up. Then also, as you get more OE shipments in the second half and like I said earlier, they're going to be about 10% higher in each quarter, in the next three than they were in the first quarter, that will drive some higher low charge hardware coming out of our wheel and brake business too. But other than those two factors, you got the right perspective.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, then just to clarify. Your aftermarket, your 7% to 9% aftermarket forecast, that reflects 4% to 6% global ASM growth?
componenttext: Okay, then just to clarify. Your aftermarket, your 7% to 9% aftermarket forecast, that reflects 4% to 6% global ASM growth?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And last one, SG&A as a percent of sales, Scott, was down a lot this quarter. Was there anything special there or is that a kind of number from a percentage basis that we can potentially target going forward?
componenttext: And last one, SG&A as a percent of sales, Scott, was down a lot this quarter. Was there anything special there or is that a kind of number from a percentage basis that we can potentially target going forward?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the absolute dollars that we said earlier for guidance on a quarter-to-quarter basis, kind of normal run rates would be about $34 million and another $6 million in other income and expense for a total of about $40 million per quarter, and that's very
componenttext: Yes, the absolute dollars that we said earlier for guidance on a quarter-to-quarter basis, kind of normal run rates would be about $34 million and another $6 million in other income and expense for a total of about $40 million per quarter, and that's very consistent with where we actually recorded for the first quarter. And then in addition to that, we have $2 million to $3 million a quarter in minority interest adjustments as well. So this was a very normal quarter. Sometimes, we get some volatility either from foreign exchange or from compensation-related costs. And if you look at the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of last year, those are both drivers of higher than normal levels. So I would characterize Q1 '11 as right in line with our expectation for the full year and what I would consider to be a normal spend rate.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I was referring to the $285 million in SG&A costs and 15% of sales in the quarter.
componenttext: I guess I was referring to the $285 million in SG&A costs and 15% of sales in the quarter.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Again, also that's an area where as you look longer-term, we've got a lot of efforts around the company to try to make sure that that growth rate is slower than the sales growth rate. So, those are things that don't turn quarter-to-quarter but over time,
componenttext: Again, also that's an area where as you look longer-term, we've got a lot of efforts around the company to try to make sure that that growth rate is slower than the sales growth rate. So, those are things that don't turn quarter-to-quarter but over time, our intent is to get more leverage off of that SG&A line by trying to grow the company faster than we grow SG&A support costs.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks a lot.
componenttext: Okay, thanks a lot.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Peter Arment with Gleacher and Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Peter Arment with Gleacher and Company.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marshall, I have a question on defense. Just trying to get at least a better clarity on your outlook for growth. You're very well-positioned giving your platform mix and really the helicopters and the high start content that you have. But trying to get a
componenttext: Marshall, I have a question on defense. Just trying to get at least a better clarity on your outlook for growth. You're very well-positioned giving your platform mix and really the helicopters and the high start content that you have. But trying to get a better understanding on how that actually looks between the OE and the aftermarket piece. Can you just give us a little color? I mean you don't need to give us the specific numbers. You have never broken that out but just how that is flowing through between OEM and aftermarket in defense?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, generally there's a larger, a little bit larger OE content than aftermarket. It kind of depends on the products. But I mean if you think about ISR, which is a great growth area, I mean you might as well call that, all of it OE because it goes straig
componenttext: Well, generally there's a larger, a little bit larger OE content than aftermarket. It kind of depends on the products. But I mean if you think about ISR, which is a great growth area, I mean you might as well call that, all of it OE because it goes straight to the end-use customer. And generally, not big replacement on it. Helicopters, that's different. I mean there, we get a fair amount of aftermarket parts, as the life of the airframe ages. So it's not like a wheel and brake business where it's primarily aftermarket. It's a split, generally a little bit higher on the OE side. You want to comment on that, Scott?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's right. Our overall, our military split is around 60% OE, 40% aftermarket and we've got good growth in both of those categories. On the fixed wing side of the aircraft portfolio, there's not a lot of OE growth. But we are getting good volume
componenttext: I think that's right. Our overall, our military split is around 60% OE, 40% aftermarket and we've got good growth in both of those categories. On the fixed wing side of the aircraft portfolio, there's not a lot of OE growth. But we are getting good volumes coming out of replacement and upgrade programs, both in wheels and brakes and in the C-5 reengining program. So there's good activity in the aftermarket retrofit, even in that side of the equation as well. I would characterize both as growing.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, because the reason I asked because there's a record number of helicopters versus an all-time level even higher than we had in the Iraqi surge and I was wondering whether you are seeing an incremental pickup there in terms of your aftermarket and tha
componenttext: Okay, because the reason I asked because there's a record number of helicopters versus an all-time level even higher than we had in the Iraqi surge and I was wondering whether you are seeing an incremental pickup there in terms of your aftermarket and that's really driving a lot of its growth. What you're saying, it seems it's more balanced than what?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's much more balanced than that.
componenttext: It's much more balanced than that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you very much.
componenttext: Okay, thank you very much.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Joe Nadol with J.P. Morgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Joe Nadol with J.P. Morgan.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd like to hone in a little bit more on the landing gear situation and i understand that maybe you can't comment fully on it because of the circumstances. But maybe I missed it but where are you planning to move that capacity to? And Scott, what other fi
componenttext: I'd like to hone in a little bit more on the landing gear situation and i understand that maybe you can't comment fully on it because of the circumstances. But maybe I missed it but where are you planning to move that capacity to? And Scott, what other financial implications -- well if you could size, what kind of a charge we might see and what other financial implications might there be in terms of cost savings down the road?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We talked about the operations part of it and Scott can talk about the potential financial impact. First of all, the volume in that Cleveland plant is not as large as we have in some of our others. So the overhead absorption isn't as good as we would like
componenttext: We talked about the operations part of it and Scott can talk about the potential financial impact. First of all, the volume in that Cleveland plant is not as large as we have in some of our others. So the overhead absorption isn't as good as we would like. It's more of the fact that we just don't have the kind of volume that we need, although our cost base was right there and we might make a different decision. So it's too early to say that because we're still going through our negotiations and that may change the situation on it. But we have other plants in Tennessee, in Toronto, in Poland that all are capable of taking more capacity. So we'll just have to see how this negotiation unfolds to see whether or not we'd follow-through with the closure. Scott?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, if I could just jump in there, one more thing Marshall on the operations. Is this a former Coretec or Goodrich plant? And what products are made there?
componenttext: Actually, if I could just jump in there, one more thing Marshall on the operations. Is this a former Coretec or Goodrich plant? And what products are made there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's a fair amount of Boeing product on both the military and the commercial side. So, there's some, a little bit of business jet.
componenttext: There's a fair amount of Boeing product on both the military and the commercial side. So, there's some, a little bit of business jet.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the other part of your question relative to the magnitude and how we're thinking about it from a return standpoint, I can't really comment specifically on the value of the charge, if you will. But if we do take the decision to close to
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the other part of your question relative to the magnitude and how we're thinking about it from a return standpoint, I can't really comment specifically on the value of the charge, if you will. But if we do take the decision to close to facility in the quarter that we'd make that decision, we would both give you the amount of the charge, help you identify how much of it is cash versus noncash and our belief would be a sizable piece of that would be noncash related to facilities, pension curtailment, things like that. And then adjust our guidance accordingly. But in terms of the ability to pay back the cash portion of that charge, that would happen relatively quickly. It would take probably a year and a half to wind things down. But once you get the volume and the cost restructured, we would expect to pay that back pretty shortly over the next couple of years after that.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We will go next to Doug Harned with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: We will go next to Doug Harned with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned, when you talked about cash in the earnings release, you mentioned that you have ongoing investments related to the 787, related to the A380. Could you talk about that investment profile looks for those two programs right now as you go forwa
componenttext: You mentioned, when you talked about cash in the earnings release, you mentioned that you have ongoing investments related to the 787, related to the A380. Could you talk about that investment profile looks for those two programs right now as you go forward the next few years?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a couple of areas of investment. One is recorded in CapEx, the other's in our nonproduct inventory, where as we ramp up in the cell and thrust programs for both 787 and A350 and then later on, the CSeries and MRJ, we recorded a preproduction
componenttext: Yes, there's a couple of areas of investment. One is recorded in CapEx, the other's in our nonproduct inventory, where as we ramp up in the cell and thrust programs for both 787 and A350 and then later on, the CSeries and MRJ, we recorded a preproduction excess over average of those programs in inventory. The total increase in investments there, we would expect this year to be in the $300 million range in total from a cash standpoint. Again, those are across all three of those programs. And then on the CapEx side, much more modest in terms of what we would attribute to raised capital associated with those three programs. But its capital expenditure going on, not only to support higher rates but also to reposition capacity, consolidate capacity and make sure that we can deliver better margins as a result.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: What I'm getting at also is when you look at the trajectory of these two programs, do you expect to see a significant ramp down in the 787? And then the A350, when is the timing of when that might come in given that production obviously is a little bit fu
componenttext: What I'm getting at also is when you look at the trajectory of these two programs, do you expect to see a significant ramp down in the 787? And then the A350, when is the timing of when that might come in given that production obviously is a little bit further out?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We would expect 787 to ramp down and then A350 is approaching peak spend right now and we'll stay at that level for the next year or two in the CSeries, MRJ, the GTF program, Neo as well increasing. So I think our view would be it's sustained at about a l
componenttext: We would expect 787 to ramp down and then A350 is approaching peak spend right now and we'll stay at that level for the next year or two in the CSeries, MRJ, the GTF program, Neo as well increasing. So I think our view would be it's sustained at about a level of investment that we're talking about for 2011 for the next couple of years. But the program composition would change but the absolute dollars probably don't change a whole lot.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then if I can, just one quick one on aftermarket. When you look at geographically where you're seeing the demand right now in the aftermarket, can you contrast how it looks today versus a year ago? In other words, Asia versus developed markets, are yo
componenttext: And then if I can, just one quick one on aftermarket. When you look at geographically where you're seeing the demand right now in the aftermarket, can you contrast how it looks today versus a year ago? In other words, Asia versus developed markets, are you seeing a change there?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Asia has bounced back very nicely and we see that in our MRO shops. We've got much more activity going on there now than we did a year ago. So, that was a significant difference. And I would say that's moved the most. And we've seen a steady progress
componenttext: Yes. Asia has bounced back very nicely and we see that in our MRO shops. We've got much more activity going on there now than we did a year ago. So, that was a significant difference. And I would say that's moved the most. And we've seen a steady progression up in Americas, I mean in North America and Europe has kind of been just steady.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just presuming, as the very new fleet ages in emerging markets, you're getting into initial heavy checks, those sorts of things. Is that a correct way to think about this?
componenttext: Just presuming, as the very new fleet ages in emerging markets, you're getting into initial heavy checks, those sorts of things. Is that a correct way to think about this?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, remember that our parts are on different cycles than heavy checks. Many of them happen well before you get a heavy check. Wheels and brakes about a year out on narrow profits. And the cells that are out there, you still get piece parts but you don't
componenttext: Well, remember that our parts are on different cycles than heavy checks. Many of them happen well before you get a heavy check. Wheels and brakes about a year out on narrow profits. And the cells that are out there, you still get piece parts but you don't get kind of complete overhaul of the cells until they're up there like five to seven years. So you could get the heavy check and already have been doing, replacing parts of ours that are through the warranty period and have gone through kind of a number of cycles that weren't replacement.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Scott, with respect to Forex and the current position, the $25 million benefit you talked about for 2012, where does that look now with the $1.45?
componenttext: Scott, with respect to Forex and the current position, the $25 million benefit you talked about for 2012, where does that look now with the $1.45?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: At the end of the first quarter, we were still sizing that as $24 million favorable in 2012 over '11 at an exchange rate of $1.60 on the sterling, $1.42 on the euro and $1.03 on the Canadian. So it would be a little bit worse than that. But we're 75% hedg
componenttext: At the end of the first quarter, we were still sizing that as $24 million favorable in 2012 over '11 at an exchange rate of $1.60 on the sterling, $1.42 on the euro and $1.03 on the Canadian. So it would be a little bit worse than that. But we're 75% hedged so it's only on the 25% that's unhedged that would move a little bit. So I don't have the exact numbers but I would guess it's around $20 million to $21 million now.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then, Marshall, with respect to the aftermarket growth you're seeing, can you give us some color across your eight businesses? Are each of those fully engaged in the growth at this point and what's growing conservatively faster and slowe
componenttext: That's great. And then, Marshall, with respect to the aftermarket growth you're seeing, can you give us some color across your eight businesses? Are each of those fully engaged in the growth at this point and what's growing conservatively faster and slower?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, most of our businesses have -- I mean, all the large businesses had double-digit growth. Aerostructures, our piece parts are right on plan. As I mentioned earlier, the Asian MRO backlog is the best it's been in the last 10 months
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, most of our businesses have -- I mean, all the large businesses had double-digit growth. Aerostructures, our piece parts are right on plan. As I mentioned earlier, the Asian MRO backlog is the best it's been in the last 10 months. We have continued good bookings for majors. We booked more majors at this time this year than we had last year year-to-date. So that's a good trend. As I indicated earlier, in our Interiors business, every book to bill indicator's green. We got orders in place to support sales through the next half of the year, which is very good in that business. Wheels and brakes had a very strong first quarter and we expect that trend to continue. The out of production planes, ones that are no longer in production at Boeing and Airbus have come back and we're getting stronger sales there. So, as we look around the business, even our smaller businesses are seeing good prospects on the aftermarket.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And one clarification on the restructuring, given a piece of that is military. Would any of the restructuring charge potentially be recoverable?
componenttext: And one clarification on the restructuring, given a piece of that is military. Would any of the restructuring charge potentially be recoverable?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't believe so, Myles. I haven't heard that mentioned. But I don't know the answer to that. If it was, I don't think it would be a material change.
componenttext: I don't believe so, Myles. I haven't heard that mentioned. But I don't know the answer to that. If it was, I don't think it would be a material change.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks a lot.
componenttext: Okay, thanks a lot.

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Eric Hugel with Stephens.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the aftermarket growth, is there any sort of DeCrane acquisition benefit in those aftermarket sort of year-over-year growth numbers?
componenttext: In terms of the aftermarket growth, is there any sort of DeCrane acquisition benefit in those aftermarket sort of year-over-year growth numbers?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's a very small amount of benefit there because there is some aftermarket associated with those products. But it's negligible. It wouldn't change the rounded numbers in terms of our growth rate.
componenttext: There's a very small amount of benefit there because there is some aftermarket associated with those products. But it's negligible. It wouldn't change the rounded numbers in terms of our growth rate.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. Marshall, what explains the sort of the greater than ASM growth in the aftermarket you're experiencing when you sort of look at it?
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. Marshall, what explains the sort of the greater than ASM growth in the aftermarket you're experiencing when you sort of look at it?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we're very well-positioned in businesses like our wheels and brake business that cover a broad spectrum of airplanes. And they're very strong on the A320s, as well as our Aerostructures business is very strong on A320s. And I think that
componenttext: Well, I think that we're very well-positioned in businesses like our wheels and brake business that cover a broad spectrum of airplanes. And they're very strong on the A320s, as well as our Aerostructures business is very strong on A320s. And I think that that combination plus the coverage we have on this aftermarket, particularly the ones that are still in production but as I just said earlier, the legacy, we call legacy but they're really the airplanes there, no longer in production on the OE side, have bounced back too. So I think we're positioned just very well.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just one little that in terms of your guidance, you raised I guess the biz jet from about 30% growth to 30% to 35% growth in the quarter? I guess prior you said 6% of that was organic. Has that number changed?
componenttext: And just one little that in terms of your guidance, you raised I guess the biz jet from about 30% growth to 30% to 35% growth in the quarter? I guess prior you said 6% of that was organic. Has that number changed?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it would change. It's double-digit organic now for the full year.
componenttext: Yes, it would change. It's double-digit organic now for the full year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks.
componenttext: Great, thanks.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to try to push again on the margin question. Very good margin performance in the quarter. You recognize the mix shift to OE that you're looking for for the rest of the year. But we've had times in the past where you've pointed to that and th
componenttext: I just wanted to try to push again on the margin question. Very good margin performance in the quarter. You recognize the mix shift to OE that you're looking for for the rest of the year. But we've had times in the past where you've pointed to that and then done much better on the margins than you expected to and you've talked a lot about the overhead and efficiency improvements, things of that nature. To the earlier question on SG&A and your response to it, you've been talking about those things for several quarters and SG&A was growing while you're talking about that now it finally steps down. You talked about how it takes a lot to come through. It seems like maybe we're at the beginning of that actually hitting the P&L. So is that the right way to think about? How much headroom is left in those processes and how much upside is there to what you're telling us on the margins going forward?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Over time, we believe we can continue to drive margins well above where they are today. Some of the benefit that we got in the first quarter is because of the mix. The aftermarket was growing at 12% and the OE was half that growth. When you have that mix,
componenttext: Over time, we believe we can continue to drive margins well above where they are today. Some of the benefit that we got in the first quarter is because of the mix. The aftermarket was growing at 12% and the OE was half that growth. When you have that mix, we can drive margins up aggressively in that kind of a mix environment. We're expecting that to change a little bit for the balance of the year where the OE side is going to be growing very rapidly on a sequential basis whereas aftermarket, we don't think it's going to grow that fast. So that mix dynamic does have a difference when you're looking quarter-to-quarter. But absolutely, we think we can drive margins higher than where they are today and higher than where we expect them to be this year because of those leverage points. When you get volume growth, you get growth again in the aftermarket, which should be sustained for a very long period of time. We can grow through that and drive both the top line at double digits and improve the margins at the same time. The drives a lot of EPS.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one follow-up on the aftermarket as well. Marshall, last quarter, I have in my notes you're discussing the sort of monthly progression where you said January was a lot better than the fourth quarter trend. And I just -- it's a little
componenttext: Great. And then just one follow-up on the aftermarket as well. Marshall, last quarter, I have in my notes you're discussing the sort of monthly progression where you said January was a lot better than the fourth quarter trend. And I just -- it's a little short term but I think it can maybe help. The market has clearly expressed some concern on fuel and the airline customers maybe pulling back a little. So maybe if you can talk about the Feb versus Jan, March versus Feb, even quarter to date if the trend is held to get us more comfortable.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The trend has held. We've had selected businesses where one-month was down and then back up the next month. But generally, the trend overall has held very well. And I think you can tell that by the sequential growth that we've had. So I have no reason to
componenttext: The trend has held. We've had selected businesses where one-month was down and then back up the next month. But generally, the trend overall has held very well. And I think you can tell that by the sequential growth that we've had. So I have no reason to think we're not going to continue this.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks a lot.
componenttext: Okay, thanks a lot.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to George Shapiro with Access 342.
componenttext: We'll go next to George Shapiro with Access 342.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marshall, or Scott, if I look at the aftermarket growth this quarter and maybe my numbers are a little bit off, it looks like the actuation only grew around 5% and the cells grew like 14% and electronics grew 15% or 16%. Any reason why the slower growth o
componenttext: Marshall, or Scott, if I look at the aftermarket growth this quarter and maybe my numbers are a little bit off, it looks like the actuation only grew around 5% and the cells grew like 14% and electronics grew 15% or 16%. Any reason why the slower growth overall in the actuation aftermarket?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The only business where we saw some declines in aftermarket were on the landing gear area, where we had some higher growth in 2010 and what we're expecting in 2011 and that showed true in the first quarter. But all of the other businesses across the compa
componenttext: The only business where we saw some declines in aftermarket were on the landing gear area, where we had some higher growth in 2010 and what we're expecting in 2011 and that showed true in the first quarter. But all of the other businesses across the company, we have eight businesses that have significant aftermarket components. All of the other ones were flat or up.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: One of the things you have to understand George about the Landing Gear business, that aftermarket goes through Boeing because they own the proprietary property on the landing gear. And landing gear aftermarket is lumpy because it really depends on years a
componenttext: One of the things you have to understand George about the Landing Gear business, that aftermarket goes through Boeing because they own the proprietary property on the landing gear. And landing gear aftermarket is lumpy because it really depends on years ago when the deliveries were. And so it kind of goes in cycles and you can't, just really can't look at it on just a quarterly basis.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: But my point there Marshall, if this quarter's aftermarket revenues pull through the year, you said you'd be at the high end. In reality, this actuation, this landing gears probably lower than what it's going to be for the rest of the year so you can make
componenttext: But my point there Marshall, if this quarter's aftermarket revenues pull through the year, you said you'd be at the high end. In reality, this actuation, this landing gears probably lower than what it's going to be for the rest of the year so you can make it an easy argument that the subsequent quarters should be higher than the first quarter, no?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we don't really think the landing gear issue was the one quarter aberration. We expect that volume to be lower this year than last year.
componenttext: No, we don't really think the landing gear issue was the one quarter aberration. We expect that volume to be lower this year than last year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other quick one, Scott. The increases in the adjustments this quarter, they were just related to performance or was there any relation to the increased production rates that we've been seeing occur?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other quick one, Scott. The increases in the adjustments this quarter, they were just related to performance or was there any relation to the increased production rates that we've been seeing occur?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011

componenttext: We get a little bit from some of the A320 volumes just the way the contracts work we add volumes this quarter. So that's a fairly predictable piece of what to expect in terms of adjustments each quarter. But other than that, there were no other production rate increases that flowed through the quarter. Those were picked up in 2010.

componenttext: Okay, thanks a lot.

Well, my number's $12 million.

Okay, $12 million about approximate. So the other question is I guess you said that George that in the quarters now is it like five or something where you are kind of consistent below in your estimate of your benefit period of rising production rates. componenttext: All of the production rate increases that have been announced to date are already reflected fully in the contract. So it would have to be a new rate increase from either Boeing or Airbus just to have an impact on the contracts from a volume standpoint.

componenttext: Okay. But he said they might go out. So if they do go up, they would presumably the quarter that they kind of make that official, you would have an incremental benefit?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just going back to business jets for a minute. You bring it up a little bit more see a little bit organic growth. Could you comment on exactly where the business jet market you're seeing that and is it related to what specific sort of model is it related
componenttext: Just going back to business jets for a minute. You bring it up a little bit more see a little bit organic growth. Could you comment on exactly where the business jet market you're seeing that and is it related to what specific sort of model is it related to?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Jason relative to the growth or to the increase in our guidance for this year, it's actually more in the regional markets for 2011. So we mix regional business and General Aviation all into that OE category. So that was the benefit year-over-year an
componenttext: Well, Jason relative to the growth or to the increase in our guidance for this year, it's actually more in the regional markets for 2011. So we mix regional business and General Aviation all into that OE category. So that was the benefit year-over-year and the reason for our increase is more of activity we've seen on the Embraer 170, 190 aircraft and some of the large to turboprops that go into the regional fleet. If you look out beyond '11, there is a good growth story coming on business aircraft. The large cabins are doing well now, the mid cabins, we expect those to start increasing rates sometime in 2012. I don't think we're going to get much benefit in terms of shipments in '11 but I think once you get to next year, we should be on a good stable, growing platform for several years after that and we're very well-positioned to take advantage of that. And we've seen, the macro things that we look at like hours, business jet landings, things like that. They're all trending in the right direction. The level of inventory of the fleet, the pricing and the used aircraft market of the business jet. All of those things pointing towards production rate increases in 2012 which would give us again growth in that market channel next year.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the fact in the aftermarket, we are getting significant double-digit increases in the wheel and brake for business only, I'm not talking about anything else. Just the business GA side indicates that we are marching down half of that. That continue
componenttext: I think the fact in the aftermarket, we are getting significant double-digit increases in the wheel and brake for business only, I'm not talking about anything else. Just the business GA side indicates that we are marching down half of that. That continues, it should have some effect on the OE rates down the road.

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the clarification on the drivers of this year.
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the clarification on the drivers of this year.

componenttext: I just wanted to ask a couple of questions on Microtecnica. And you are paying relatively a full price for it. You highlighted significant growth to come. What sort of growth rate do you see in that business? And just maybe clarify, you're paying 11.5x EBITDA for it. What sort of it have or what sort of EBIT margin is it, please?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Relative -- I'll answer the financial question. I mean relative to EBITDA margins, that business operates at about the same level that Goodrich does overall. So that's 18% and 19% EBITDA margin. So we would expect fair amount of D&A to come through with t
componenttext: Relative -- I'll answer the financial question. I mean relative to EBITDA margins, that business operates at about the same level that Goodrich does overall. So that's 18% and 19% EBITDA margin. So we would expect fair amount of D&A to come through with the purchase accounting. So while it will be accretive initially, we'll get better accretion as we move on a drive some of the cost synergies through that acquisition. Marshall, do you want me to comment on the business?

headline: Goodrich Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start. Microtecnica is primarily an actuation business. It fits very, very well with our European actuation business. It gains entry into Augusta, the helicopter side which we have no business there before. And they have been growing at a very nice r
componenttext: I'll start. Microtecnica is primarily an actuation business. It fits very, very well with our European actuation business. It gains entry into Augusta, the helicopter side which we have no business there before. And they have been growing at a very nice rate and have significant amount on European helicopter business besides Augusta. And when you add back to some of the military trainer and the Europe fighter, the growth rates look very, very healthy in the next several years. I do think on top of that, it will allow us to get some of our products into some of those customers we haven't been in before. So it fits very nicely. It also allows us to -- it has some capacity. It allows us to move where we're capacity constrained in our European business, to move capacity in there. So in addition to the growth, there's also a fair amount of cost synergy for us.

componenttext: Well, there might be greater opportunity in that but we will be very cautious on the defense side because what we don't want to do is by into a declining market. And so, there is something that fits nicely with our ISR business or helicopters, for instance, we will take a look at it. But we don't want to buy into an area that is likely to get cut. We're looking harder in the commercial side. But if we found the right ISR bolt on, we'd probably consider it.

componenttext: Well, the valuations have come up, no doubt about that. But a lot of it depends on whether or not you get into a bidding situation and Microtecnica is a good property and there were several strategics in there, trying to acquire it. Fortunately, we've had a lot of synergies. But if you compare that to what we did on DeCrane cabin systems where you're talking about a depressed market in the business jet, we got that down in the six area, commercial systems was in between that. But I think we're seeing a heated-up M&A market. And it will become harder and harder to buy at lower multiples. But if we can get the right synergy in a particular acquisition, we'll go forward. But we're just not going to trade dollars for dollars.
